item.title: Dark Patterns after the GDPR: Scraping Consent Pop-ups and Demonstrating their Influence
item.description: New consent management platforms (CMPs) have been introduced to the web to conform with the EU's General Data Protection Regulation, particularly its requirements for consent when companies collect and process users' personal data. This work analyses how the most prevalent CMP designs affect people's consent choices. We scraped the designs of the five most popular CMPs on the top 10,000 websites in the UK (n=680). We found that dark patterns and implied consent are ubiquitous; only 11.8% meet the minimal requirements that we set based on European law. Second, we conducted a field experiment with 40 participants to investigate how the eight most common designs affect consent choices. We found that notification style (banner or barrier) has no effect; removing the opt-out button from the first page increases consent by 22--23 percentage points; and providing more granular controls on the first page decreases consent by 8--20 percentage points. This study provides an empirical basis for the necessary regulatory action to enforce the GDPR, in particular the possibility of focusing on the centralised, third-party CMP services as an effective way to increase compliance.
item.author: ([Submitted on 8 Jan 2020])

item.title: How To Test Your React Apps With The React Testing Library — Smashing Magazine
item.description: Testing gives confidence in written code. In the context of this article, ‘testing’ means ‘automated testing’. Without automated testing, it is significantly harder to ensure the quality of a web application of significant complexity. Fails caused by automated testing may lead to more bugs in production. In this article, we’re going to show how React developers can quickly start testing their app with the React Testing Library (RTL).

item.title: .NET Core Summer Event 2020
item.description:
This is the recording of the 2020 edition of .NET Core Summer Event. The event is a one day mini-conference with an international speaker line-up (including 8 MVPs) focused on software development with .NET Core.
Check out the event website: https://dncse.nl
Thanks to our sponsors for making this event possible: - Info Support (https://www.infosupport.com) - DotNed, the Dutch .NET User Group (https://www.dotned.nl).
See the list of sessions below. You can click each timestamp to skip to that specific session. The first part of the stream (about 1 hour) contains only a splash-screen that showed while attendees were joining the live stream.
This is a list of the sessions:
00:58:27 - Blazor Components deep dive by Ronald Guijt 01:58:23 - What’s New in .NET Core 3.0 and .NET 5.0 for Performance and Memory-Aware Folks? by Konrad Kokosa 02:58:24 - TDD and the Terminator – An introduction to Test Driven Development by Layla Porter 03:58:23 - The Rise of Software Supply-Chain Attacks – How Secure is your .NET Application? by Niels Tanis 04:58:22 - Anatomy of ASP.NET Core Requests by Steve Gordon 05:58:23 - eShop on Dapr: build microservice applications the easy way by Sander Molenkamp 06:58:23 - Beyond REST with GraphQL in .Net core by Irina Scurtu 07:58:21 - “You are what you eat!”, or how to fight data with Jupyter Notebooks for .NET by Daniel Costea 08:58:24 - Lessons learned building our own API gateway by Jonathan Mezach 09:58:23 - gRPC & ASP.NET Core 3.1: All you need to know by Anthony Giretti
If you want to see more technical content, check out dotnetFlix: https://youtube.com/dotnetFlix.
--
item.author: (NET Core Summer Event)

The good thing is that I’ve finally found the courage to transition to this slick and fast site you’re browsing now!

item.title: Fraunhofer Heinrich Hertz Institute HHI
item.description: Through a reduction of data requirements, H.266/VVC makes video transmission in mobile networks (where data capacity is limited) more efficient. For instance, the previous standard H.265/HEVC requires ca. 10 gigabytes of data to transmit a 90-min UHD video. With this new technology, only 5 gigabytes of data are required to achieve the same quality. Because H.266/VVC was developed with ultra-high-resolution video content in mind, the new standard is particularly beneficial when streaming 4K or 8K videos on a flat screen TV. Furthermore, H.266/VVC is ideal for all types of moving images: from high-resolution 360° video panoramas to screen sharing contents.
